## Quarto

Quarto enables you to weave together content and executable code into a finished presentation. To learn more about Quarto presentations see <https://quarto.org/docs/presentations/>.

## Bullets

When you click the **Render** button a document will be generated that includes:

-   Content authored with markdown
-   Output from executable code

# Code

## Basic code

When you click the **Render** button a presentation will be generated that includes both content and the output of embedded code. You can embed code like this:

```{r}
1 + 1
```

## Advanced code
:::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="36%"}
We can put some code on this side...
```{.r code-line-numbers="|1,2|4,5"}
rand <- rnorm(100)
summary(rand)

gam <- rgamma(100, shape = 1)
summary(gam)
```
:::

::: {.column width="58%"}
And put the results of the code over here or something.
```{r}
#| echo: false
rand <- rnorm(100)
gam <- rgamma(100, shape = 1)
```

```{r}
summary(rand)
summary(gam)
```

:::

## Math
The basic linear model is defined as
$$ 
Y_i = X_0 + X_i \beta_i + \varepsilon
$$

## simple plots

Here we can include a plot with the code hidden.

```{r}
#| code-fold: true
#| code-summary: Plot Code

mpg %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = displ, y = hwy)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = class), size = 2) 
```

## Interactive plots

```{r}
#| code-fold: true
#| code-summary: Plot Code

p <- mpg %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = displ, y = hwy)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = class)) 

ggplotly(p)
```
